choices.D: HTTPS proxy configured on the remote server blocks the connection.
choices.C: Application-layer security features on the remote server block the connection.
choices.B: Firewall rules on the remote server block the client on port 443.
choices.A: Connectivity from the remote server back to the client is down.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Think its B: 
Firewall rules on the remote server block the client on port 443.
 • The server is up and running since other users can access the webpage.
 • The client can connect via Telnet and SSH, meaning general network connectivity is fine.
 • The issue is specific to HTTPS traffic (port 443), suggesting that a firewall rule is blocking the client’s IP.

Selected Answer: C
Curl is using certification key, so there is some sort of TLS Client Authentication configured in the Remote Server. My answer would be C.

Selected Answer: C
C. Application-layer security features on the remote server block the connection.

Selected Answer: C
The server may have increased security that is blocking the cURL request2. Even though the developer can ping the server and open a TCP socket with Telnet, the application layer security could still block specific types of connections, like cURL12.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A developer is using cURL to test connectivity to a webpage. The request times out after 10 seconds. The developer tested connectivity by using Ping and can open a TCP socket to the remote server by using Telnet. Other users confirm that they can access the webpage from their device. The developer has SSH access to the remote server and runs commands to troubleshoot. What causes the issue?

discussion.content: A is correct. The Cisco Meraki Dashboard API uses the base URL https://api.meraki.com/api

questions.question_text: A developer needs a list of clients connected to a specific device in a Meraki network. After making a REST API call, the developer receives an unfamiliar response code. Which Cisco DevNet resource should be used to identify the meaning of the response code?

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer wants to change the name of a device. The engineer submits a NETCONF request and receives a response. Which NETCONF request did the engineer submit?

Option D should be correct, but it starts with "<rpc mlns=" instead of "<rpc xlmns=".
Maybe just a typo? The other options don't seem to be correct.

Selected Answer: D
NTP is used for time synchronization.
